Pajama Goblin
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
7.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 31 aout 2019
Finally finished this game and I'd like to say that I am impressed. I have spent less than 10 hours playing and most likely won't play the campaign again. However there is a mode that is fully open only after you finish campaign and people who are inclined to write music might like it.

The game itself is an adventure inside synthesiser. You make music, basically, by solving puzzles. But at same time you learn how music works in general manner. Some puzzles are difficult if you don't want to spend much time solving them yourself. There are full solutions to the game. However, I highly recommend doing the puzzles yourself as much as you can and only looking up how to get from one puzzle to another, roads are weird.

Although, if you don't like getting lost all the time, you might want to pass this. Look up first puzzles solutions if you are unsure and decide if you are okay wandering around the digital world of Fract OSC.
 
Muhanoid
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
12.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 2 juillet 2019
An amazing audiovisual experience. The whole game is filled to the brim with electronic ambiance that blew me away, even after a second playthrough. Mogi Grumbles has been one of my favorite artists for a while, and I was not disappointed to finally get to play a game that uses his music (I know, a little late to the party). It isn't perfect, of course. The game has those floaty physics that you find in a lot of Unity games, the controls are a little wacky (played with both keyboard/mouse and gamepad) and I'm not sure why the decision was made to make you unable to jump. Other than that, I would definitely recommend this game to anybody in the mood for an amazing sound exploration experience.
 
NuclearTape
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
16.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 29 juin 2019
Do you like exploring forgotten worlds?
Do you like neon colors and pulsing synth soundscapes?
Do you ever wish you could enter TRON?

FRACT OSC might be for you.

An astounding game of exploration and puzzles, FRACT OSC is an unforgettable experience of entering a completely alien environment and fixing what has been long broken. By assembling and activating the systems that forge your path forward, you bring back life into what was once a dead and silent land. Although the game lacks combat or enemies to kill, it is not easy, either. It gives you little assistance with moving forward, and the game expects you to figure out how its mechanics work on your own. The rewards for completing its challenges are worth it.

Colorful, original, and magical, FRACT OSC is an old-school PC adventure wrapped in an 80's laser package. A must buy for any gamer who loves music. And if you have any mind-altering substances you like to enjoy, this game is extremely fun in such a state :P
 
Mentok the Mind-Taker
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
2.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 13 mai 2019
Okay.. So I had this game in my whishlist for five years. I liked the idea and I love lectronic music and random creativity, though I never really got around to buying the game, until now. And I'm glad i did. From the very beginning of the game, it just caught my attention like no other game has for a long time. :D It's full of surprises and gives off a great atmosphere with it's crazy shapes, high contrast neon lights and oh yeah.. the SOUND!!! The sound design and sequences are mesmerising (though the sound does clip and crackle like crazy at some points). I haven't beaten half of the game yet, but I already love it, and recommend it to anyone who loves the electronic sound as much as I do!

Recommandé
24.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 14 septembre 2018
This is up there with Antichamber as one of my favorite puzzle games of all time, it's absolutely brilliant. You essentially create music to solve puzzles, but you don't need any prior composing knowledge as the way you create the music is always tied to an actual physical puzzle like with any other game. On top of the fantastic puzzle design, the atmosphere is amazing and visuals are gorgeous.

Also the ending is fricking incredible. (and you unlock a nifty in-game sequencer to play around with afterwards)
5/5

738 produits enregistrés

Recommandé
15.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 19 aout 2018
I could’ve played this game for hours more. The music was so well done, and the satisfaction of solving a puzzle in this game was amazing. This game was fairly short is you didn’t just go and explore. You also have to pay attention to many things, as the final puzzle contains clues from around the world. The game had a cool, simplistic, polygonal shape look that was easy to fall in love with. Overall this game was heaps of fun, and it was a 6/10. It did have some hitches, like it was hard to find all the pieces for the end puzzles for each section, and often you couldn’t really go back and find them, or you’d have to solve a stick of puzzles. Anyway, pretty much an amazing game.

5.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 30 mars 2018
so it's a music-based walking simulator puzzle game where it's your job to get a barren neon sci-fi dreamscape playing music again. if that sounds like your bag, you really can't miss. some of the puzzles are headscratchers though (i definitely consulted the walkthru several times) and the thing you unlock for beating the game is...not exactly the easiest to use. but by now, you've probably already made your mind up if this is for you or not. i've seen some remarks about it being "incoherent" and...i can understand that. but if you like games like myst and old school synthesizers, you should give this one a college try.
 
Jax the Jaguar
478 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
10.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 18 juillet 2018
Probably one of my favorite first person puzzle/exploration games. The world is made of audio, breating in every corner, reacting when you turn a puzzle piece, intensifying for each correct step towards the solution. With a click of the mouse, you get a cursor to appear so you can click and drag to manipulate pieces of the puzzle, which works like a charm once you get used to it. The environments between the puzzles are beautiful and mysterious, and serve as nice quiet breathers between the loud puzzle rooms.

Fract OSC is a world that is simply a joy to uncover and restore.

Lucian
306 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
16.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 2 juillet 2017
This game has fantastic music that gets more epic the farther you get. The process of solving puzzles unravels a bit more of the melody or beat and when you finally make it click by combining all the clues for each final area challenge, you feel like some kind of DJ puzzle god :P The built in music loop maker is also fun, with more tools unlocking as you get farther in the game. I think there are even tools for saving your songs externally!

Minor problems include empty space making you waste time or being unsure of if it's connected to a puzzle or not. Graphics are a little sloppy but I like the style in general.

The main problem I had, just like with Antichamber, was FINDING the final chapter. I completed everything I could find, but in both cases, the game didn't seem to end. For Fract OSC, I wandered around and around and could see where I was meant to go, but had no clue how to get there, for the longest time.
 
FarewellVHS

Was a pretty amazing game when is all said and done with due to the fact even the single player mission was enjoyable, but only two things I wish happened with this game. I wish the studio was part of the main world instead of it's own zone & secondly I wish for there to be a sequel in the pipeline due to this game being pretty amazing. If they decided to link up with such software like FL Studio or something like that to make their studio in this sequel better that would be amazing.

Other then that I can't falut the gameplay or much of anything minus the game in single player can be a touch short, but still enjoyable. Yes I can recommend this game because of the music.

188 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
9.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 17 juillet 2016
どうにかクリアー出来たのでレビュー。

５／10

良い
・キューブを動かすパズル
・グリーン色のエリアのシンセサイザーの打ち込みパズル
・オープンワールドの様な作りで好きな所から手を付けられる

悪い
・マゼンタ色のエリアのシンセサイザーの打ち込みパズル
・機械の配線を繋ぐようなパズル
・音楽


パズルを解きながらゲーム内で、スタジオと呼ばれる場所にあるソフトウェアシンセサイザーの機能をアンロックしていく事が目的。シンセサイザーをモチーフにしている（筆者はそう思っている）だけあって音ゲーになっているような、なっていないような微妙なところもあったりする。

言葉のないゲームで、ある程度自由に行動できるオープンワールド的な作りになっており、３色（シアン、マゼンタ、グリーン）に色分けされた廃墟のようなミニマルなローポリゴンの世界をプレーヤーが自らパズルを見つけ出し、それを解いて、廃墟となっている世界に（再び？）エネルギーを流れさせるといったよう展開になっている。ゲーム中は言葉や説明が全く無いが、ゲームの冒頭にチュートリアルがあり、操作方法を簡単に教えてくれ、またそれ以上の操作はゲーム中では要求されないので問題無いだろう。また、パズルを解くと光の柱が立つなど、目に見えて変化が出るので言葉や説明がなくてもはっきりとした結果が得られるようなゲームデザインになっている。

パズルには複数の種類があり、シアン、マゼンタ、グリーンと色分けされたそれぞれのエリアの特徴となっており、プレーヤーを飽きさせないようにゲームプレイに多様性をもたせようとしているのは好感が持てる。但し、ひたすら「組み合わせ」を試すようなあまり良い出来とは言えないパズルが多く、うんざりさせられることになる。一部を除きパズルは基本的にノーヒントになっていることもそれに輪をかけている。では、本当に機械的に全ての組み合わせを試してみて、正解を探すのかと言われれば、そうではなくて、パズルを解くときには目に見えるビジュアルの変化を頼りに試行錯誤を繰り返す形となる。目に見えた変化があるのなら簡単なのではないかと思われるかもしれないが、そこはやはりパズルゲームであり、一筋縄ではいかない作りになっている。（インタラクトすべきものの数が多い）例えば、難しいパズルだとソフトウェアシンセサイザーの５×１６のマス目に、プレーヤーに与えられた１６のコマをグラフィックイコライザーの様なビジュアルの変化を頼りに任意で並べるなど。

良いと思ったパズルは、純粋に観察力と思考力を試されるモノで、動かす順番と位置を考えるものや、並べる数と発動させるタイミングを考えるもの。

悪いと思ったパズルは、組合せ爆発に近い、ひたすら組み合わせを変化させるものや、何故そうなるのかといった、パズルを解いた後も法則がいまいちよく分からずにすっきりしないスイッチパズル。

シンセサイザーがモチーフになっているゲームだと思うのだが、パズルを解く前も解いた後もイマイチな音楽しか流れないのはちょっと残念。

アンロックされるシンセサイザーの機能などはやはりおまけ程度、お遊び程度。

一応、筆者は独力でクリアーできた（初見で９時間ほど）ので無理ゲーだとは思わないが、かなり不親切ゲームだとは思う。

日本語非対応だが、言葉は殆ど無いに等しいので、操作方法が分かれば遊べる。不親切なゲームに抵抗がなく、興味のある人はセール時にでもどうぞ。
 
兎訛りの兎
205 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
2.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 6 juillet 2016
I followed this game from its early stages of just free alpha builds you could test until its final release. All I can say about it is that it is amazing, if you like digital sound and music puzzling its hard to be dissapointed by this one. It might be a bit vague on what to actually do, which I guess can be a downside for some people, but the game is really open for exploration and it rewards it with mystical but beatiful evironments!

There is a logic to most puzzles but it can feel like trial and error at some points, but in doing so you will get alot of different results in terms of sound and visual wich I really like cause I find it satisfying seeing different outcomes of things even though it might not be correct.

Pros:
-Awesome sound
-Visually appealing
-Rewards experimenting
-Open world exploration

♥♥♥♥:
-Can be vague on what to do and where to go

All in all, if you are a fan of neonworlds and synthesizer sounds its amazing!
 
Goode

Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
16.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 3 juin 2016
Hammer Spiel.
Ich würde echt zum Kauf empfehlen. Manche Rätsel sind knifflig, aber nicht zu knifflig und vieles schafft man auch nur durch ausprobieren oder erkunden. Was ich auch recht nice finde ist das Studio, in dem man eigene Musik machen kann. Ich finde auch geil, dass das Studio nicht einfach ein Menübildschirm sondern auch wie mit richtigen Geräten dargestellt ist. Ein Hauptmenü gibt es nicht, was aber nicht schlimm ist. Zu dem finde ich es in dem Spiel auch echt spaßig, dass man in dem Spiel auch mit Musik an diversen Rätseln einfach mal rumspielen und Musik machen kann.

Fazit: Ich kann das Spiel nur empfehlen
 
PKTM01234
270 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
10.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 11 mars 2016
An absolute musical thrill.

There are no words and the game expects you to be intelligent enough to find out how everything works. You will get frustrated, but you will also feel rewarded for figuring things out on your own... Which is what the game is centered around; exploration/discovery.

You really learn to appreciate the impact music has on a game, and will most-likely groove-out and try certain things to make new beats.

Overall, the game is about trial and error, and does a fantastic job of keeping the player interested and wanting to try more. It also has a built-in dope sheet to create your own music and upload straight to youtube.

Discover your inner DJ.
 
Beepin

Subtle Roy
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
9.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 17 mars 2016
I have never been this impressed by a game's visuals before. Every single part of the game has had obvious work put into it, and the world reacts to your presence in increasingly surprising ways. As you explore through the game and solve more puzzles, the areas around you evolve increasingly, giving a sense of progress and satisfaction that kept me motivated to continue. The music builds gradually as you solve a puzzle and seeing the area that you just traversed light up and make a great song continues to be rewarding every time.

I was afraid to buy this game for a while due to my computer not meeting the minimum system requirements, but it somehow ran the game just fine with only a few problems. Even if the audio was interrupted in several places, Fract OSC was a wonderful experience regardless.

Unfortunately because of how intricate the game is, it is also extremely confusing in certain places. You will likely be spending a long time trying to find the correct path, and may need to watch video walkthroughs at certain points, as some of the paths are darker and less noticeable than the scenery, causing me to wander very far in the wrong direction. This is especially inconvenient when backtracking through each level once the end has been reached. The teleportation hubs mitigate this a bit, but they were sometimes located relatively out of the way and made travelling a bit inconvenient. The solutions to certain puzzles were also placed in very strange locations, and were sometimes presented in ways that were difficult to decipher. The vibrant design of Fract OSC can be disorienting, but it still proves to be enjoyable for its mind-blowing architecture.

Aside from that, there will likely be more than a few instances where you are so amazed by what's happening around you that you walk straight off ledges and fall to your death. This is an unavoidable side effect of such a beautiful game.

Ultimately, I'm very happy with what I got for my money, and if you like exploration games with maximum freedom, then I highly recommend that you buy this one.
 
The Jumping Ghost

Christoph
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
7.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 24 janvier 2016
FRACT OSC is a compelling audio/visual experience. Throughout the course of the game, the player completes a variety of puzzles, sculpts the soundtrack, and slowly deciphers a symbology highly resonant of electronic music synthesis and sequencing. I found the greatest reward of the game to be exploring beautiful neon clad low-poly environment, which was a great experience in and of itself.

I thought the puzzles were decent - nothing amazing, but well crafted, and they ocasionally had me stumped. I wish there were more "ah-ha" moments, and some instances felt repetetive, or draged due to the necessity of repeatedly traversing its physical strucutre. On the whole they were enjoyable, but I did not find them to be the strong suit of the game.

The music elements are quite nice. The soundtrack is frequently derived from the actual solution to various music puzzles, yeilding a personilized experience. The only "downside" to this connection between solution and soundtrack, was that often working solutions did not yeild the most musical results (noting that this opinion is solely due to my own subjective musical tastes). Overall, I found this to be a very minor detail, and almost a moot point next to the highly polished sound design and music production.

The "studio" is a nice feature - allowing you to compose your own music using various sequencer and parameter modules unlocked through completing puzzles. As someone used to writing electronic music outside of the gaming experience provided by FRACT OSC, I did personally not find it to be a particularly useful tool. Especially using an xbox controller, the system is time consuming to navigate and somewhat limited in its parameters. That said, I could see the Studio being enjoyable to someone new to the experience. To me it was primarily novel for its existence, rather than its functionality.

I definitely suggest checking out FRACT OSC, especially if you like electronic music, puzzle games such as Antichamber, and exploring open audio/visual worlds. It's not perfect, but few (if any) things are, and this exprience is certainly worth a play.
 
Polytope

0
Non recommandé
2.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 6 décembre 2015
Produit remboursé

FRACT OSC to nudny, bezgłośny symulator chodzenia po blokowatej mapie, z puzzlami na poziomie przedszkola.

Jest reklamowany jako gra zorientowana dookoła muzyki, lecz przez 90% czasu gracza otacza absolutna cisza. Kilkanaście "muzycznych" zagadek rozłożono na wielkiej mapie, przez co zdecydowanie większym wyzwaniem jest ich znalezienie niż rozwiązanie. Po zakończeniu zadania typu "prowadź laser lusterkami" lub "włóż zieloną kostkę w zielone pole a niebieską w niebieskie" zaczyna coś grać, ale po oddaleniu się na 10 metrów znowu nastaje cisza.

W zewnętrznym, malutkim hubie, oprócz wejścia do wspomnianej ogromnej mapy, jest "studio": kwadratowa płytka otoczona ekranami, na których można kontrolować muzykę odblokowaną w zagadkach. O ile mi wiadomo - oprócz kilkunastosekundowej zabawy z pokrętłami, przez które muzyka gra inaczej a światełka mrugają w inny sposób - nie ma tu absolutnie niczego interesującego.

Może po przejściu wszystkiego robi się bardziej melodyjnie? Nie wiem, mnie nie chciało się szukać kolejnych zagadek.
 
fri

Recommandé
6.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 15 octobre 2015
This is definitely a very "indie" game in that honestly a lot of things could use some more explaining. (Or at least better introductions to teach you the visual language the game uses.) I'm ashamed to say I had to look up a puzzle solution only to discover that the puzzle I was trying to solve wasn't the puzzle you were supposed to be solving.

However once you figure out what it is you're supposed to be doing, it's quite a lot of fun, although it is incredibly easy to get lost when wandering around the world. Thankfully there's a "teleport to last station" option to make it easy to get back to landmarks if you do find yourself lost.

My only criticism is that the game is a little short; you can finish it in a couple of hours.

Fract OSC is a really interesting game. It doesn't really tell you much of anything at all which is likely a major detractor for many, but you're basically repairing destroyed instruments through puzzles and things. 294 produits enregistrés

Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
20.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 29 octobre 2015
tl;dr- If you like puzzles, music and exploring, I recommend giving the game a try. I like the abstract nature and lack of handholding, and I especially recommend this game to my programming cohort ;).

I grabbed this game in a bundle- and this game single-handedly influenced my decision to go ahead and get the bundle. This game is at first glance, sheer EYE-CANDY! Although, as I will go on to explain, it is much more than that. As a person who loves point-and-click games- this game is a 3D adventure/exploration with puzzles and P&C without the inventory.

I want to quote the developer here, "Fract is not just about exploring a world or solving its puzzles, but it's about taking a journey of musical discovery". I feel this statement is so true. As a self-proclaimed music and puzzle aficionado, I thought the combination of lights and sound was an excellent foundation, and the abstract nature of this game did not slow me down at all. Some people may feel the game begs the question "what do I do?” to which I pose the answer- try stuff. The game has a good feedback loop- you will realize the game is not linear and it is not a sandbox. The game will respond to "correct actions" by lighting stuff up, which should naturally incline you to try more of that stuff. The finale of the game culminates into a musical puzzle symphony experience.

The game has some replay value- (in fact, I’m feeling the urge to go and replay after posting this review- keep in mind it’s been a few months since I played last). You can also go into your “studio” and make your own beats and loops- even though that’s not my “thing” that’s still a pretty cool feature . All in all a great game, and I recommend you give it a try.
 
Aeriana Filauria

Évaluation publiée le 2 octobre 2015
Ho acquistato questo gioco perchè mi ha semplicemente ispirato..e non ho sbagliato.

All'inizio ho faticato molto per comprendere lo scopo del titolo, mi sono ritrovato spesso a girare a caso e a risolvere enigmi senza ben capire cosa stessi facendo ma il gioco è anche questo: un mondo ♥♥♥ regole diverse dalle nostre, tutto da scoprire, da vivere e da far rivivere.
Più si scopre del mondo e più si capisce quanto è affascinante questo gioco, fino al grande finale.

Assolutamente consigliato se vi piace l'esplorazione, la scoperta e il ritmo.

---------------------------------------------

I bought this game because of an inspiration..and I was not wrong.

At first I struggled to understand the purpose of the title, I often found myself lost solving puzzles without knowing what I was doing but the game is also that: a world with different rules to discover, to live and revive.

More you discover the world, more you understand the fascination of this game 'till the astounding ending.

Absolutely recommended if you like exploration, discovery and rhythm.
 
CyberWYX
645 produits enregistrés

Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
1.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 27 septembre 2015
I don't regret buying this game. In fact, I almost love it. But I also can't recommend it to you, because it's just so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ annoying sometimes.

Good:
- The most beautiful fast travel system of any game I've ever played
- Cool premise, sleek design
Bad:
- Two puzzles which gave me the "solved" sound cue and visual after I made one move at random, and then required me to finish the rest of the puzzle in order to progress. Discouraging.
- The 'platform rotate' control is a pain to operate with a mouse.
- In the middle of one puzzle, dropping me through a solid platform above a deep pit. Twice. Which brings me to my next point:
- Backtracking. The default walk speed is too slow, and running requires you to constanly hold shift. Also, there's no jumping. Which is annoying when you assume you can jump, and walk straight into a pit that doesn't kill you, but does require you to restart from some randomly chosen place a minute's walk from the puzzle you were working on.
- For a game that's mostly about sound, the sounds are kinda annoying.

If, like me, you enjoy games like Myst, with the first person puzzles, no characters or combat, and a contemplative (read: glacial) pace, you'll probably get some enjoyment from this game. If you're just here for the cool synths, go buy Garage Band or something.
 
Pilcrow

1,523 produits enregistrés

Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile

Recommandé
6.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 7 septembre 2015
Un jeu d'exploration/puzzle pas extraordinaire mais toutefois très sympathique, ayant pour thème la musique.

Le jeu se décompose en 3 zones pour 3 types de puzzles différents. Le début des zones étant simple pour se complexifier à la fin. Chacune des 3 zones se finit par un puzzle qui requiert d'avoir été attentif lors de votre exploration. A défaut, vous devrez retourner sur vos pas pour récolter les indices que vous aviez manqués.
Une fois les 3 zones complétées, un puzzle final vous attendra. Un peu bordélique mais il reste intéressant, et il vous permettra de débloquer le "studio", une interface de création musicale dans le jeu.

Pas de grands défauts. Le seul reproche que je pourrais énoncer à son égard est une vitesse de déplacement un peu faible malgré le sprint. Au moins, une option permet de sprinter automatiquement lorsque vous avancez.
 
Harest
1,091 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
21.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 2 aout 2015
Fract OSC is a beautifully minimalistic puzzle-exploration game. The puzzles and layout of the world are seperated into three main areas; blue/cyan, green, and red/pink. They vary wildy from block puzzles that test spatial awareness, to connecting conduits ala Pipe Dream. At the end of each main puzzle is a step synth music puzzle. the main puzzles were really well thought out, and the final puzzzles in each section involve interesting clues and solutions.

The visual astetic of the game is wonderful and reminds me of Tron. Neon colored lights, mostly monotone base colors make it look very 90's cyberpunkesce. The music is not as present as I thought it would be. The music that is there though, it is really immersive and does come to life because of your actions. That is really cool.

The step synth puzzles were a little annoying, because they required a bit too much trial and error. Outside of the main areas there is not much to do. The game is also a bit on the short side. It does'nt have much replayability other than to mess with the in game music maker. I would recommend this game if you like point and click adventure games or something like Antichamber. If you don't like obtuse puzzles in games then this is not for you, but if you love exploration and ambiance, then you will love it like I did.
 
Overlord_TweaK
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
33.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 9 juillet 2015
Als ich das Spiel zum ersten mal gestartet habe, bin ich in eine bizarre Welt gerworfen worden. Ein wichtiges Element von Fract OSC sind Klänge. Stück für Stück kann man in diesem Spiel Aufgaben lösen, um damit die Welt von Fract OSC wieder in Gang zu bringen. Um den Spieler die teilweise recht langen Strecken zu erleichten, gibt es eine Art Aufzugsstationen, die man auch als Speicherpunkt sehen kann, und die man freischalten muß, indem man zu der entsprechenden Station hinläuft.
Danach kann man zwischen den schon freigeschalteten Stationen hin- und herreisen, was ein wirklich tolles erlebnis ist.

Ein Wermutstropfen ist, und das hat Fract OSC mit Antichamber gemeinsam, das wenn man das Spiel fertiggespielt hat, es zuende ist. Naja, nicht ganz. Wer Musikalisch begabt ist, hat mit Fract OSC quasi ein komplettes Musikstudieo zur verfügung. Ansonsten bleibt dem Spieler nur die Möglichkeit, das Spiel nochmal ganz von vorne anzufangen.

Recommandé
9.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 28 juin 2015
I recommend the game, BUT it comes with risks.

The risk being crackling. and when you're trying to immerse yourself in this musical world, crackling audio is a big deal. The devs told people who experienced it to go into the options menu in-game and uncheck a box, and that got rid of about 70% of crackling for me, but 30% is still a lot for a sound based game.

The devs told us that people with low end sound cards would experience the crackling, but even some people with high end setups also said they had audio problems. I would guess about 20% of players reported this audio issue.

To my knowledge, the devs still haven't been able to pinpoint a commonality for why so many users across the spectrum have had crackles. and as a result, no patch has ever been released.

But the game is very pleasing to the ear(when there's no crackling, of course), and it's puzzles are challenging. As you solve puzzles, you unlock elements of a synthesizer. Once you unlock everything, you can use it to make your own music in the game.

If you get the game, I would buy the game on a sale and just hope that you're not one of the unlucky ones who experience the audio crackles.
 
GodBlessAssad
0

Évaluation publiée le 9 juin 2015
In the age where synth music is king, FRACT OSC rises to the occasion. This is a game all about manipulating music to solve puzzles and find out information about a strange civilization. The three instruments, Synth, Pads, and Bass are used seamlessly to give the experience an extra kick. Plus, the entire time your doing the game, your unlocking stuff for an in-built music creator. A few puzzles will irratate you, but otherwise, this is a solid title. Play this if you love music.
 
Fidgie

Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 17 mai 2015
10/10

TL:DR - Absolutely amazing to experience!

------------------------------------------------

Absolutely blown away by this game. I've played many of these abstract, atmospheric games on Steam, and this one is really channeling something from the creators on a level far above the rest. I really don't even want to describe it too much.

So what to say. I will describe a single moment in my experience of the game:

I had been roaming around, fiddling with things, and appreciating the environments for a while. I wondered off of a lit path into a long, low cave out of curiosity. I followed it for a while. As it began to open up, a soft warm glow came out of the shadows with the low wisps of a distant tune. I walked farther, approaching a strange object protruding from the cave floor and reaching nearly to the ceiling. This object was the source of the soft pink glow and the tune, now filling the air, mesmerizing and somber. It was so beautiful. I sat for nearly half an hour staring at the object and feeling the slow pace of its low melody.

As I tried to finally leave, I found it difficult somehow. I knew the melody would fade, and this, strangely, made me sad. I tried again and the same feeling came to me. As it took me I realized the loneliness and sadness inherent in this object and in this place. That this beautiful setting and this melancholy tune would only exist together here, as they are, deep in this cave, inside this fractured world, only seen or heard by those few who venture here, guided by nothing.

I could only think one thing ... "thank you".
 
Vernum

Évaluation publiée le 4 avril 2015
Its alright. But that's all. Perhaps its meant for someone with a deep interest in making electronic music but otherwise its a bit forgettable. I played it through to completion. Didn't stay around for 100%

The bad:
-Puzzels types are repeated over several times. Only 5 different ones in total by my recolection.
-Very little guidence as to what you are supposed to do/what you can interact with
-movement is slow (why are there even 2 speeds?)
-background music becomes grating
-very short (3hrs) ((maybe thats a plus >_<))

The good:
-aethstically interesting (but its an indie game so thats a given)
-Final puzzle is rather chalanging
-Controls are fine
-Performance is fine

Other:
-Crashed once after taking a teleporter.

In conclusion, there are many games in my library that I would rather have spent these 3 hours on.

Évaluation publiée le 10 mars 2015
This game is fantastic! It really feels like you have stumbled onto a lost silent world, and as you slowly start to piece together the dead technology, you add color and beauty to the world through music, light, and motion. With a distinct flavor I have not seen anywhere else, FRACT OSC is an awesome game that I would recommend to anyone with a palette for adventure or synth music.

An additional and large feature is the synth studio, and I have yet to explore it to its full capacity. Having not much experiance in the creation of music nor the tools to do so, I cannot give an accurate description of how good or bad it is. All I know is that it's fun, enjoyable to mess with, and as far as I know pritty powerful for being in a game.

Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
6.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 5 mars 2015
음악을 걷고 음악을 탐험하는 1인칭 어드벤쳐 게임.

음악이라는 컨셉이 참신하다. 또한 음악의 3요소인 리드, 배스, 패드 세 가지 요소를 기본으로 한 퍼즐의 구성 또한 신박하다. 기본적으로 '음악'이라는 컨셉을 활용했으며, 그 안에서 적당히 머리 굴리게 만들어져있다. 머리 굴려가면서 퍼즐 푸는 재미도 있는데다가 각 퍼즐을 풀고나서 해당 퍼즐의 의미를 하나하나 깨달아나가게 되면 소름까지 돋게 된다. 단순히 어드벤쳐 게임이라는 요소만으로도 뛰어난 점수를 받을만한 게임.

거기에 퍼즐을 풀어나갈수록 게임의 '스튜디오'에서 활용할 수 있는 요소들이 하나하나 해금된다. 그리고 이 해금된 요소들을 활용해 나만의 음악을 만들 수 있게 된다. 그렇게 설정한 것들을 저장하거나 불러와서 활용하는 것도 가능하고, 스튜디오에서 완성한 음악을 녹화해서 유투브에 공유하는 것까지 지원해놨다. 게임치고 굉장히 음악이란 요소에 신경을 쓴 모습을 보여준다.

게임이 조금 짧은편이긴 하지만 게임의 컨셉과 그 컨셉을 제대로 화려하게 표현해낸 그래픽이 굉장히 돋보여서 게임이 짧다는 단점이 상쇄가 될 정도다. (그리고 요런 스타일의 게임에 멀미를 심하게 느끼는지라 오히려 게임이 짧은게 낫기도 하고...) 그 정도로 대단히 참신하고, 또 아름다웠던 게임.

단, 게임 자체는 굉장히 불친절하다. 튜토리얼도 사실상 없는 수준에 가깝고, 길안내라던지 그럴싸한 도움말 같은것도 전혀 없다. 모든 것은 플레이어가 알아서 찾아나가고 깨달아가면서 플레이해야 한다. 게임의 전반적인 힌트가 되는 부분도 전부 플레이어가 스스로 찾아나가야 하기 때문에 불친절한거 싫어하거나 게임 상에서 알려주는 바가 전혀 없으면 심하게 헤메는 이들에게는 추천하기가 조금 그렇다.

음악이라는 컨셉을 가장 잘 활용한 게임이 아닐까 싶다. 그만큼 상상 이상으로 충격으로 다가왔던 게임이기도 하고. 특히나 게임 좋아하는 뮤지션들이나 음악에 관심이 지대한 게이머들이라면 다른거 다 제껴두고 반드시 해봐야 할 게임이라고 추천해주고 싶다.
 
Kutar'k
1,558 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
18.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 24 janvier 2015
Alright so I have a strange relationship with this game. What happens is, I'll begin playing, feel absolutely euphoric while doing so (everytime you solve a puzzle it feels amazing) then i get to an insanely obscure puzzle, get stuck on the geometry, or just get super lost, then i want to murder the game. Its a very love hate relationship we have, me and FRACT.

But its funny, no matter how furious i get at the game.. eventually, I always come back. The siren songs of the synth pads and dayglo beauty of the landscapes consistently reel me back in. The visuals and sound truly make this game remarkable and set it apart from many a first person puzzle game.

I will definitely recommend the game, but don't feel bad looking at walkthrough's, keep your sanity

1,147 produits enregistrés

Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
6.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 19 février 2015
I don't think is really an "exploration" game in the real sense of the word. It's a first-person puzzle game with somewhat nonlinear progression and some extra stuff hidden away if you search for it. I'm fine with that being the case, since it's really quite good, but it's a bit misleading to really call this an exploration game.

The core gameplay consists of three main zones each focusing on two puzzle types. One puzzle type tends to be involving both movement and problem solving, while the other type is a sequencer-type thing about trying to get all nodes activated at the same time or in a certain order. For the first type, the closer you get to solving the puzzle, the louder the music swells. The second type, your puzzle solution creates a melody of its own (though there's probably a very finite amount of solutions, but there's definitely some degree of freedom present regardless.) There's also some code-type objects hidden away that you need to be on the lookout for.

I don't want to describe too much the gameplay because there is a good bit of figuring out how stuff works and there's enjoyment to be had in that, tinkering with new puzzle objects until you understand what the puzzle is, and each branch of the main zone adds complexity and challenge to the puzzles along its sequence, although there's nothing really too tough here.

Also, I should say that the game is -beautiful-, aesthetically, just, perfect, I love it. The music is pretty nice too though perhaps a bit homogenous, but there's not an excess of it and the silence is used to great effect as well. Presentation-wise this game knows exactly what it's doing and does it well.

I think the game is a bit short for the asking price (though I got it 75% off, so, can't complain) and it's not quite as deep of an experience as I was expecting but I would certainly say it's a good game and definitely worth checking out.
 
rory
910 produits enregistrés

Recommandé
15.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 14 janvier 2015
I have played a decent number of games in my time. Some I'd call adequate at best, some I'd call great, some I'd call worthwhile. This title in particular breaks the mold in a way, but to simplify: I tried "Superbrothers: Sword and Sworcery" some time ago and loved it for the music, the scope, the narrative which was only told in frames and tiny sections. It is the closest thing I can think of to compare to FRACT OSC. However... unlike Sword and Sworcery, this game bypasses pesky things like conflict and resolution, and tells a story that cannot be told with plain words. It is not long, or passionate about things like character building, or a good example of combat with many -isms that make it stand out, and yet it is special and thus deserves attention.
It is not perfect, but FRACT OSC utilizes what is special about the medium of video games with more finesse and more beauty than anything else I have seen. It embodies WHY I play games. It is marvelous.
 
Akninirith

0
Recommandé
17.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 5 janvier 2015
This game is amazing, a must own for anyone who collects unique titles.
It is beautiful, both visually and audibly.

How would I describe this game?

A musucal exploration adventure with very little instruction.

My best description of this would be that you are inside some kind of
synth sequencer. However, it is currently broken. You must adventure through
its expansive digital world and solve puzzle to repair its components piece by piece.

Doing so also creates a musical environment.

As you solve each puzzle and replace each piece, another feature of the sequencer is
unlocked in the main area for you to use.

Thus, as you repair the sequencer, you can actually use it in the main area.

I can not recommend this game highly enough if you enjoy innovative or music based titles.
 
Sogono
921 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 4 janvier 2015
Graphically, musically, architecturally and in application of construction, FRACT OSC is a very beautiful game. You explore a Tron like alien world, discovering new areas, solving puzzles and resurrecting long dead machinery. I felt like I was exploring the inside of Altair IV from the 1956 film The Forbidden Planet.

There are a few impressive things about this game, firstly the whole game (except for the main menu) it one giant open world puzzle game with an intricate transport system very much like the rail system in Riven (1997). You can explore off the beaten path and all you will find is beautiful level design all around you. The puzzles are abstract, but all are built on the same musical foundation so I did look at a few hints with my first chosen area, but after that I didn't need to look at any as all the puzzles are solidly designed and don't rely on any silly tricks to solve.
This is still (9 months after the release) version 1.0 of the game, it has been toughly tested. I don't feel like enough attention is drawn games that have been built well, but this is one of them.
5/5
 
Decompiled
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
38.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 14 janvier 2015
A rather trippy musical game. It's overall style makes me feel like I'm in Tron, the first movie, but with a few minor twists which also give it an odd Myst-feel to it (maybe the obscurity of some of the solutions and the amount of exploration available). It's actually surprisingly rewarding, because as you solve more puzzles, you have more control over your studio, which motivates you to complete all the puzzles, so you have full control over that part of the machine. By the end of the game, you have a much cooler, and more advanced machine to work with, and then you can refine your beats even moreso.

(Un)fortunately, there's an unlock for it too. Un-, because you can cheat to the end and spoil yourself, like the brat you are; more about the destination, and avoiding a good trip. Fortunately, in case you accidentally delete your old save, or lose your progress, or are just overall frustrated with the game, and want to skip the hassle (Hint: awareness and critical thinking are your firiends with these kinds of games. Explore a bit, think outside the box for a moment, grow a pair and do something risky for the hell of it, or if you feel desperate, or to freefall off a part of the environment for fun of it), and have some fun making your own music.

Beating it is it's own reward, and freaking beautiful while at it.
The final puzzle makes your own ending theme tune. Mind you, you can adjust at any time as you make progress, and don't need to backtrack; they also contribute to the beats you can use to make your tune too. Probably one of the coolest parts of the puzzle.
 
[DFC] Itnetlolor

0.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 9 janvier 2015
I've been wandering around the world presented to me in this game for over 15 minutes, and I have no idea what the Fract is going on.

I randomly stumble upon puzzles to complete, but there is no guidance, no direction - it is purely by luck that I advance to the next puzzle. I don't believe adding a map, or some dialog to point the player in the right direction would infringe upon the difficulty of the game much. Graphically, the game is simple but effective and I love the feeling that I have been thrown in the middle of a Blue Man Group performance - both are confusing and awe inspiring.
 
Zombie Brew
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
9.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 5 janvier 2015
Honestly I don't normally write reviews seriously but this game shocked me with how beautiful and imaginative it was. The puzzles felt fun and original and it neither felt like I was reusing old solutions nor was the main core mechanic of each set being under-used (i.e. being introduced then taken away for another mechanic).

The exploration is really nicely done, it felt like that nicer type "do it yourself, we're not giving you a map or anything", and while it was confusing at first until you realise how pathing works, it made me feel a lot more free and immersed within the game.

The artstyle is something I was a big fan of, very Tron like yet it wasn't sickening with neon. The colours stood out and made key areas and visuals clear, as the rest of the game is rather dark in shading.

The music was atmospheric and beautiful, and probably the game's highlight. Every little part of the game, from the puzzles (which I noticed changed either modulations or notes on the main synthesizer) to the little expanding platforms changes the music in some way and makes the world feel magical and mysterious. The atmosphere it creates is one that enchanted me from the beginning to the end.

The little unlockables at the end that unlock parts of the synth to use are probably one of the most desirable unlockables I've ever come across in any game. Unlike Crackdown's orbs or Meat Boy's bandages (both games I enjoyed but did not feel invested in the collectables, even though they changed the game in some way), this game goes for short but sweet collectables that add modulations and functions to the additional synthesizer which can be used to make pretty tracks without needing too much experience in music design itself. In fact, the game sort of teaches you about certain aspects of music design and effect through its puzzles, like one for instance which works on timing decay.

If I had to say there was something lacking, it would be the loss of (at least I don't think there is) a story or underlying message. But in this element I feel perhaps a directed story may have spoiled the looser narrative of exploring the world. Also, there isn't much replayability outside of the synth, but the synth does kind of make up for that by itself.

All in all I had a great time playing this game and I continue to play around with the synth. I would absolutely recommend buying this game if you can, it's well worth your time and money.
 
breakbeast
476 produits enregistrés
0

14.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 6 décembre 2014
Fract OSC is one of the most moving gaming experiences I have ever had the privilege of having. For me, it evoked feelings that only a select few first-person exploration games, like Metroid Prime or STALKER, have managed before. The sheer scale of Fract's world provided me some legitimate awe as I scampered through its crumbling mega-structures and coaxed ancient, dilapidated machinery back to life.

In addition, the game has, perhaps, one of the best finales I've ever seen in a game, with all of your solutions to previous puzzles coming together and building on one another to a very satisfying climax.

Add to that a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ soundtrack by MogiGrumbles, and you have a game I'm going to revisit often.
 
Brightsider
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
8.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 30 novembre 2014
Fract OSC is the 80s lovechild of Tron and Myst. This auditory odyssy offers an Alice in Wonderland ride that, while it delights the senses, ultimately makes little sense from a traditional storytelling perspective. The only explanation the player receives about the story is before you ever buy the game or install. After that, the player is subjected to a variety of sights and sounds in what seems like an immense world, but how all of these pieces tie together leaves a player more puzzled than satisfied. But, if the player can suspend disbelief and the need for a strong narrative, the game does impress the senses.

Offering a midi style toolbox (i.e., 'the studio') with which to build tracks, Fract pays homage to the demo scene of the 80s and 90s. Tools within the studio can be unlocked organically by making progress in the single player game, or a player can opt to bypass the story and unlock all components of the studio immediately.

My only complaint is a compliment to the game-- I enjoyed it so much, I wish there was more to the single player story. (I only got 8 hours out of the game, using no walkthroughs.)

I highly recommend Fract if the game is on sale. I still recommend the game at its "normal" price point, although that recommendation is not as strong at full price due solely to the limited story content.

Either way-- Fract is a game that won't soon be forgotten.
 
Mazian

Évaluation publiée le 11 octobre 2014
Brief review.
one of my favorite minimalistic games EVER, including system shock, which is saying A LOT. It's like the world from Reboot except 15 times more mysterious, massive, and dark. and a lot like Myst except the puzzles are even more enjoyable, awarding, and unique. But my favorite part of the game is that the massive world around you changes as you fix and connect all sorts of titanic machinery. It's awesome to see turbines, generators and beams of energy moving, flowint, working, and connecting together as you repair this sleeping dimension. (and nothing in the game is behind the safety of invisible walls where the player may only assume that other things are out there. Every single thing that exists in the dimension from start to finish, for anyone who loves to explore). And I find that the minimalistic graphics help improve the immersion of trying to figure out what this world is and why you are in it. "Am I standing on oddly shapped soil or 100% pure crystal? Are these temples or factories you're exploring, or titanic hand held tools built by alien gods??? If you have an imagination, you would love every second this game reveals to you. (and lots of exploration and secret areas. LOOOOTS of exploration and secret areas). my only regret is that I want a FRACT 2, which I'm almost positive will never happen :'(

9.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 27 septembre 2014
FRACT OSC is an exquisite game of exploration, making music, and solving puzzles to restore life to a dead world. It is not the most mentally taxing puzzle-adventure game every made, but the satisfying ka-chunk of epiphany hits even outside of the puzzles themselves. Figured out a puzzle? Ka-chunk. Figured out how the fast-travel system is structured? Ka-chunk. Figured out how the world reflects what you've accomplished? Figured out where to go next? Figured out the final, climactic, cascading, beautiful puzzle? Ka-chunk. Ka-chunk. KA-CHUNK. FRACT OSC is a festival of delights, and it's all the more powerful for how much it demands that the player figure things out on her own.
 
Comte de Saint-Bernard
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 24 septembre 2014
The closest thing I can compare FRACT to is the time I showed up in in Kurdish Iraq with barely a month of Arabic lessons (note: Kurds prefer to speak Kurdish, not Arabic). I wanted to venture out from my hotel and explore the city of Erbil. But instead I mostly stuck close to our Peshmerga guards and my friends in our medical service team as we shuttled from location to location. Still, our group braved the communication divide a few times, usually in marketplace situations where Iraqui Dinar could do all the talking. The question lingered in the back of my mind each time we stepped out, “How well are we going to be able to read our environment?” Some navigational anxiety was sated by the fact that I still had familiar objects to read and relate to – things like trees, buildings, cars, and friends. Our group stuck together in this setting, leaning on one another to make sense of our alien surroundings.

In FRACT OSC, I had no language, objects, or friends to relate to. It was just me, exploring an alien world made of abstract shapes and synthesizers.

I needed my music-literate buddy, Max, to help make sense of the world.

FRACT OSC invites me into extreme illiteracy. It’s like landing in a country I’m even less prepared for than Kurdish Iraq. My FRACT illiteracy reminds me of my own privileges. And just how hard it must for people to understand the world with limited access to friends and family. FRACT OSC got rather unpleasant at times, but I also think it’s brilliant. It drew discomfort out of my own inability to read the world. It drew me into reliance on somebody other than myself. And reminded me that understanding often comes from community.

For the record, I haven’t completed the game. But you can be sure I’m saving it for the next time Max comes over.

Read more: http://gamechurch.com/feeling-foreign-in-fract-osc/
 
M Joshua
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 24 septembre 2014
A unique take on the Myst-like puzzle-adventure-exploration genre, with a heavy dose of electronic music. The player lands on an alien world, populated only by a flora of luminescent polygons and strange contraptions. Tron comes to mind when thinking about what this whole world looks like, but there isn't a lot of well-known examples that rely heavily on neon lighting and simple geometric shapes. The trailer gives a good idea of what the game looks like.

Similar to Myst's level design, each contraption is located on a seperate section of the map (islands, in Myst's case). So in a sense, it's non-linear. The player gets to choose where he heads out first, and the order in which the contraptions are tackled don't really affect how the game turns out.

What's interesting about this game is that solving the puzzles creates music "tracks". One of the machines spits out a drum loop, another one some chords, and due to the nature of the puzzles, there are usually a few possible solutions for each one. At the end, you get to play around with your creation, remix it, put in some effects... it's actually a lot fun !

There's even a surprisingly apt step-sequencer located at the map's main hub (your spawning spot, basically). Each puzzle solved unlocks a module in the step-sequencer (bass-line, lead synths, pad sounds, etc.), so one you've finished the game, you can give it a go and try to create your very own electronic jingle. Don't get me wrong, it's not a professional studio tool, but it's still a very nice way to finish off the game.

Pros
Very cool visuals
A nice twist on the Myst-genre (if there is such a thing)
Nice soundtrack
Cool synthesizer and step-sequencer at the end that rewards you for your hard work playing the game :P

♥♥♥♥
Puzzles are a little too simple, would have liked a larger arc that spans accross the entire map
Playthrough is a little short
 
Kayemef

This is a strange game, I must say. I'm not really into indy games but I decided to buy the indiebooth gold pack mainly it seemed like a good deal. This was the first of the indie games in the pack I tried, and I must say I was amazed.

FRACT OSC takes place in a world where everything is fueled by sound. You have to allow music to flow by powering different machines, and then trying to recreate the essential 'beat' of the song to open the gates to the next area. Along the way you get to explore the mysterious TRON-like world as well as jam to awesome electronic music.

Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
1.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 18 aout 2014
While I haven't beaten the game entirely, I have played enough to have a decent feel for it all together. This game, with it's focus on exploration, sounds, and visuals, is a rather breath of fresh care amongst the army of first person puzzle games the indie market has churned out. There's something eerie, yet comfortable about traveling through the dark, neon worlds of Fract OSC. Solving puzzles at your lesure with only a few audiable cues leaves you with a challenge that's not overbearing, but at the same time still asking to be completed. I think the main reason why that is, is because nothing is telling you to complete it. The game drops you right in the Fract world, where exploration is the draw, and the puzzles locking you away from exploring more.

The droning, yet not harsh soundtrack adds even more to the relaxing atmosphere. My only gripe is that while the sound is there, it's a rather silent game, in which either more ambience or an actual musical soundtrack is needed at times.

Fract OSC isn't an exploration game with a goal or story to tell, nor is it a puzzle game seeking to challenge you. It's a game that keeps your brain active enough to explore it's digital tunnels without pressing you to do so. It's a game that can put you to sleep, and that's not a bad thing.
 
Grumbleboots
480 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
44.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 10 juillet 2014
This game is so unusual. Technically, all the different influences it puts on you as the player are sublte. But, there are so many of them. And, once you adapt to the situation, it's very appealing. There really is a bliss factor to the game.

HOW TO BEST DESCRIBE THE GAME EXPERIENCE...
I've tried several descriptions in this review before. None of them have felt appropriate enough; the best I can say for them is that they were not wrong, just not right enough.
But, that's both the trick and the beauty behind FRACT OSC! In order to discuss it, you have to explain how you've interacted with a series of interconnected, interrelated musical art installations in a virtual space ─ fairly abstract installations, at that.

Getting blunt about it, the game/experience essentially is teaching you fundamentals [and a few finer points] of step sequenced electronic music. Imagine if the makers of the Roland MC 505 built an ancient city driven by this kind of sequential input to make stuff work.

For me, there is a truly soothing quality to the game. It's also one of the very few puzzle games I'm willing to play.
If you enjoy things like ambient electronica, I can't recommend this game enough.
 
artisan002

Kpiddy
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
1
Recommandé
6.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 3 aout 2014
Spielgewordener Synthwave-Traum mit allzu starren Puzzles

Spielwelt gewordene Synthwave. Ein fiebriger Traum aus Neon, das im zäh-verschwitzten Rhythmus von wuchtig daherwalzenden Synthlinien zuckt. Allein das wird dem ein oder anderen schon den Mund wässrig machen können. Und genau dieses Versprechen kann Fract OSC auch durchaus halten.
Denn der grafische Stil, mit dem das Spiel seine labyrinthartige Welt präsentiert ist oft atemberaubend und schlichtweg wirklich schön. Dutzende fremdartig wirkende neonglühende Strukturen und geometrische Gebilde, die sich mit der allumgebenden Musik bewegen und im Synth wiegen, aufgetürmt bis an die kuppelartige Decke; riesige seltsame Berge am Horizont versprechen traumhafte Ausblicke; blinde Flecke wollen zum musikalischen und farbigen Erblühen gebracht werden.
Die ein wenig an Cyberspace-Fantasien der 80er erinnernde Welt entwickelt, gerade anfangs schon aus ihrer grafischen Präsentation heraus einiges an Zugkraft.
Einfach nur die Frage, was hinter der nächsten Ecke kommen mag, erzeugt Spannung und Erwartung.

Die Tatsache, dass man mit behutsamer Erforschung der Umgebung und dem Lösen diverser Puzzle immer größere Teile der Welt 'aktiviert' und mit Farbe füllt, treibt diesen Faktor noch mehr.
Denn er vebrindet sich mit einem weiteren Versprechen, das Fract OSC mindestens suggeriert: Diesen Synthwave Traum in Neon mitformen zu können. Alle Puzzle sind musikbasiert und involvieren damit stets irgendeine Form von Komposition. Sogar eine ganze Synth-suit steht zum Austoben im Hub bereit. Die Musik, die die Welt des Spiels zum schwingen und wabern blinkt, ist also nicht einfach nur irgendwelche... es ist die eigene. So zumindest das suggerierte Versprechen.
Doch in der Praxis erweist sich dies Versprechen oft als eher illusionär.
Die Rätsel sind meist recht konventionell und repetitiv konstruiert. Welche Töne dabei erzeugt werden, ist bei manchen daher gar nicht erst variabel, da sie nur eine Lösung haben, deren Schritte dann mit Tönen verbunden sind; bei anderen scheint es variabel aber erweist sich oft als seltsam unflexibel. Nicht selten steht man vor einer Komposition die allen Indikatoren nach eine Lösung sein müsste, aber einfach nicht den 'winstate' auslöst. Allzu oft macht sich das Gefühl breit, dass es nur ein bis drei feste Lösungen gibt und alles weitere schlicht nicht bedacht wurde.

Das Gefühl die Welt wirklich krativ beeinflussen zu können, schwindet damit mit jedem Puzzle ein wenig mehr. Dass die musikalische Gestaltung der Spielwelt dabei ebenso hervorragend ist, wie die grafische und dass einige der Rätsel tatsächlich sehr clever mit Harmonie, Intervallen und Rhythmus spielen, verschwindet damit zunehmend hinter zu viel Routine.

Fract OSC ist damit ein Puzzle-Explorationer, der vor allem durch seinen grafischen Stil im Zusammenklang mit seiner Musik in Staunen versetzen kann, als Spiel aber letztlich nicht viel mehr ist, als ein interessanter aber etwas ernüchternder erster Ansatz, aus dem in Zukunft noch viel mehr zu holen sein könnte.
 
GeN2Mo
774 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
10.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 3 aout 2014
Fract OSC is a atmospheric puzzle game. I thoroughly enjoyed it. The first couple of hours are especially enjoyable as you wander around figuring out what the game is and how to play it. The soundscape is fantastic and the visuals match it. This is a casual game in that it does not require quick reflexes or platforming skills.
 
bUTTONpUSHER
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
11.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 7 juillet 2014
Play time ~11 hours

Story: There is no real story, but that's the beauty of it. No violence, no worries - totally family friendly. Lots of needing to figure things out on your own and interpreting abstract events as they come.

Gameplay: The game has a very unique and well executed blend of music, puzzles, and exploration. This is not found in any other game I have played. The environment oozes with music and custom tones that are affected by what you do to the environment. The game is not super easy, which is very good, because I like a challenge. The only thing I would have liked to see more is a bit more variance in the puzzle mechanics - many of them are represented as synth / equalizer adjustments to get the right combination. But overall, the game did still boast a good variety of puzzles.

Visuals and Audio: Superb. Game is beautiful in both regards. ESPECIALLY audio (of course!). There are loads of environments and the music and abstract visuals actually blend together in harmony - very nice!

Note: my review doesn't even consider the aspects of the custom synthesizer aspect of the game in which you can compose your own works of music. If you add that, and you enjoy that, this makes the game all the more enjoyable.
 
Houie
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
6.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 21 juin 2014
Creatives that have difficulty finding an appropriate and productive workspace take note: what if you could make your work from the inside out, literally? Another title for which genre conventions limit descriptive accuracy, Fract OSC is better explained in experiential terms: its somewhat like music composing INSIDE a synthesizer, a DAW that you occupy and traverse. Beginning with a locked studio suite of instruments, you explore this living-synth-world, solving puzzles involving step sequencers and percussion, progressively unlocking elements of that studio, and bobbing your head to the wonderful and reactive soundtrack along the way. Its not only atmospherically engrossing and auditorally engaging, but also makes me hope that someday the creative process of many mediums will be just like this, perhaps further facilitated by VR (I haven't gotten an Oculus Rift yet, but the game does offer VR support as well).
 
AgentM83

Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile

Recommandé
5.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 9 juin 2014
I don't often find games that make me giddy just running around. But this is one of them. I feel like the devs reached into my brain and pulled out every element I find rad and elegantly crafted it into a game. Exploration, synth-music, tron visuals, beautiful post-processing filters, dark ambiance. Really... I'm not far enough to know what I'm in for as far as storyline goes, but even without a deep story, I wouldn't care in this case.

On top of that, it's teaching me to use a sequencer. From watching the trailers, I wasn't sure how they'd manage to make puzzles out of something so organic as beats... but they've figured it out.

The only negative is that the game has crashed twice in my >1 hour of playing. It's not so big a problem as far as accessibility goes because their travel system is simple and fast. But MAAAaaaaannnn getting kicked out of that immersion sucks. Hope that gets fixed soon, yo.
 
wScottSh
469 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
6.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 30 mai 2014
This game is GREAT!

It's a blend of FEZ, Tron, Myst, and also includes a working synthesizer Application.

The world is vast and mysterious, and I found myself wandering around for hours just taking it all in. I want more games that look like this- Minimal textures with a focus on colour. The world itself is pretty open- there aren't any invisible walls, so you can "skyrim" your way up to all sorts of neat vantage points.

The puzzles are pretty neat- they aren't terribly difficult, but you'll spend just long enough trying to solve them to feel a sense of accomplishment when you do, similar to Portal. There isn't just one path, either- from the start, you have three distinct areas you can tackle, or revisit at any time. Solving puzzles unlocks more features for your synth studio.

Play this game!
 
CyberKN
383 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
11.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 20 mai 2014
To summaraize, this game is essentially a game designed by electronic musicians for other electronic musicians. How much you will enjoy it depends on how well your personal axis' lines up with these two realities (so, results may vary).

I am, personally, a bit of an electronic musician. Rebirth, Cubase, Korgs, an 808 and Ableton Live are things I like to just pull out to play with. The fact that some insane geniuses took elements from all of these (and much much more) and turned them into a puzzle game is, frankly, just too amazing for my fragile phsyche to fully explain in a way that doesn't involve my labido exploding into neon flavored goo. The fact that they then made this wet dream of mine look like a Tron redux...ooooohhh....the words, where are my words? Words = fail me.

Look, I love this game, it's that simple.

If you're anything like me, you'll probably love the game as well. If you like just one of the following: electronic music, tron, the 80s or puzzle games; there's a decent chance you will like it as well. If you're none of these...well, at least give it a try. You never know. Just remember, let yourself soak into it... Like a good Trance/Dub crossover, it takes a long time to build, then drops you into the bass heavy abyss.

This puzzle game puts you in the inside the world that used music and lights in ways that we only dream of. When you enter this new world, with little to no introduction, everything is grey and silent. As you begin to explore and try new things you kindle a fire that has been waiting for an explorer to find. With artwork from the movie Tron and a trance-like soundtrack that you create yourself this is easily a hidden gem for the gamer in all of us.

Évaluation publiée le 22 mai 2014
A pretty fun game, really cool atmosphere and great puzzles. It's really fulfilling bringing the desolate landscape to life and reviving all the dormant machines, and it has a lot of the epic moments you'd expect from that sort of objective. Kind of small though, and the in-game music composer isn't terribly flexible, only letting you play with the three instruments from the 'story' mode. Recommended, but probably best to get it on sale. It's well worth it if you do.

Zyrix
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
9.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 17 mai 2014
Interested in music producing puzzles in an abstract, alien world? Want to create your own music? Or maybe you just want to see some eerie places while listening to electronic music? Fract OSC has all of the above!

I totally recommend this gem but be aware that its' hardware requirements are quite high.
I had to set drawing distance to minimum to avoid a heavy drop in fps and stuttering (read forum posts about detailed requirements). The thing is I can run most new games on medium or high settings without any problem (Bioshock Infinite @1920x1080, full details, AA) but this one gave my PC a hard time. Maybe it lacks some optimization?

As for the gameplay - I like the idea of openness and lack of any guidance through the game, you have to discover everything on your own. Sure, I got lost few times but it was still fun.

Most of the puzzles are simple and do not require heavy thinking (nor good ear for music), some of them can be solved in alternate ways (if you know where to look and for what).

Pros:
- living environment
- electronic music everywhere
- environment design
- puzzles
- the studio
- openness

♥♥♥♥:
- performance issues
- many puzzles are too simple and they almost solve themselves
 
Leaffar
3,392 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
11.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 13 mai 2014
I used to mess around with garage band all the time on my high school's mac's, and this game totaly brought that feeling back for me. The minimalist approach towards exploration and puzzles will leave many baffled (myself included), but there are plenty of help videos on youtube that will get you through to the place where the game truly shines in my opinion: the studio.

You get to play with synthesizers! There are simple settings and more complex ones that unlock after you beat the game for those of you who actually know what you are doing. Saving songs is a cinch, and uploading them to youtube is equally so. If you have ever enjoyed creating music, this game is hard to pass up.

Good: Cool atmosphere with amazing sound quality and some intense puzzles

Bad: May be too difficult for some, no jump button

Ugly: If you mess around with the advanced settings, you can produce some ****ed up sounds.

Arbitrary number rating: 8/10 "If I'm at my computer and I'm not fapping I'm probably playing this"

Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
6.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 4 mai 2014
This is one of those odd-ball games that either you will like or hate. For music people who enjoy music-based puzzles and challenges, this is a fun game to play. There is no story, per se, but basically you solve puzzles and unlock music controlling features. Once everything is completed, you are rewarded with your own personalized DJ hub station, in which you can make fairly decent tracks and use effects to fine-tune them. THe graphics are very basic but still very pretty with it's focus being on green, blue and pink. For a price that is as cheap as this, I say buy it if you enjoy music puzzles and enjoy creating music.
 
Law Abiding Engineer
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 2 mai 2014
FRACT OSC is an intriguing game, combining a minimalist aesthetic with some challenging game mechanics to provide a solid exploration experience. The brutal minimalism does have its drawbacks however as some of the puzzles, whilst on the surface seem intuitive, don’t provide adequate response to your input. The lack of a solid ending as well also makes all the work you’ve done feel somewhat hollow, especially if you don’t have a lot of interest in creating music in the studio afterwards. Still overall it was a pleasant experience, although one I’d probably only recommend to other exploration game fans.

Read my full review here: http://www.therefinedgeek.com.au/index.php/2014/05/02/fract-osc-from-silence-to-serenity/
 
PYROMANT|C
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
7.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 30 avril 2014
One of the better first person puzzle games to come out in a few years. Stylistically drawing inspiration from electronic music, FRACT looks like an Amon Tobin album cover and sounds like Autechre's first album, "Incunabula". Everything is highly abstract: There is no backstory, no characters to meet, no text to read, just a completely desolate alien landscape to explore and try make sense of. The puzzles, once found, are nothing spectacular in themselves, but the audiovisual feedback the game provides while you solve the secrets and slowly transform an initially silent and dark mauseleoum into an echoing, pulsating thing full of ambient drones is something I ended up enjoying a lot.
 
Bastwood
1,154 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
0.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 3 mai 2014
SHORT VERSION: Not bad.

Kinda pretentious, I'll give it that, but not without merit. Admittedly not played too much but it feels like its not going to last particularly long. I would like to say that there are indeed tutorials for this game, to all those who say its confusing/too vague in its execution but personally I couldnt be bothered to watch them. The handful of puzzles I've done thus far seem a bit obscure but if youre familiar to puzzle games, I dont think you should have too much trouble deducing the logical steps necessary to solve them. So far, I dont hate it. I am wondering to what end this game leads but I dont know if thats the point; I expect a finale indicative of Antichamber in that it will be bold and eventful and thats really how im playing this; as a game similar to antichamber.

Despite this, I am not really the most interested in music "production" so im at a loss for some of its features and the sounds I can play with thus far arent exactly the kind of thing I would go for anyway. Its quite horrible in places if im being honest, its a bit sharp if that makes sense. Thats just preference though; reminds me of wearing a cheap pair of headphones on max volume. HOWEVER this is not actually the case in-game (thus far). This is me talking about the production in the "studio".

If you liked Antichamber (I did but god that game ♥♥♥♥♥♥ with my eyes) then I dont think you will be disappointed by this. It lacks some of the finesse of the former but its entertaining nonetheless. I also like playing a game with no hand-holding what-so-ever, every once in a while as I feel games seem to be getting easier and its just refreshing to actually feel like youve acomplished something.

Would I buy it for £10.99 knowing what i know, probably not but in the region of £7, probably. Saying that, I've read its about 8hrs in length which really isnt too bad considering Antichamber cost the same?? and was far less than that; you can get through that in something like 10mins?

Évaluation publiée le 30 avril 2014
This game is freaking unbelievable. I keep wondering, why haven't heard about this time till recently, when it actually appeared on Steam. I kept asking others, and watching Youtubers like Northernlion and RedPandaGamer and that was an instant buy.
At first, things would seem very.. vague at first, you have no idea where and what you're supposed to be doing. But, if you insist on exploring, you'll get somewhere eventually and there would be puzzles to solve. And yes, I absolutely love the variety of puzzles offered in this game, it gets harder and harder but it feels more rewarding - unlocking synthesizers for the studio. The Studio allows players to create and export their own music. The best part? You can visualize your creations and it will look really orgasmatic, especially when you realize that you, yourself have beaten the game while having an awesome tune blasting through your headphones/speakers

10/10 Would Recommend!

raptorman(UK)
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
9.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 29 avril 2014
The sound and visuals are beautiful. The puzzles are well crafted. When I beat this game, I actually felt something, and that reminded me why games are incredible. I also gained a much greater understanding & appreciation for sequencers, oscillators, and modulation patterns. This may be the thing that gets me back into making music after all these years.

There are minor quibbles - large, open areas where there is no sound and nothing to interact with make it pretty frustrating to figure out where to go and what to do, especially at first. This isn't helped by the slow movement speed, or that you cannot see many interactive things in normal moving-around mode. But these could be fixed pretty easily, and even if they're not, it's well worth working past them.

Strongly recommended.
 
Agius
0

This game was very reminiscent of Myst. A game where you're dropped in an unknown environment and have to figure out the rules for yourself. The game starts out almost clinically silent and every puzzle you complete adds another instrument to the background, by the end of the game you're left with a world of music and the sense of achievment is stellar.

Recommandé
12.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 27 avril 2014
Dieses musklalische Adventure-Musikstudio-Game hat Groove in den Pixeln.
Die Steuerung ist zwar gewöhnungsbedürftig, jedoch freundet man sich mit der Zeit mit dieser an.
Die Rätsel und Notenpuzzels sind eigentlich ziemlich einfach, jedoch kann man leicht vom weg abkommen und weiss nicht, wohin man soll.
Mein Tipp: Bleib auf den erkennbaren Wegen, löst zuerst die kleinen Rätsel, wagdich dann an die Indieziensammlung für die großen Rätsel.
Es gibt auch noch viele kleinere Rätsel-spielereien und Achivements, die aber nicht notwendig für den Plot sind.
